issues.description: The problem statement repeatedly refers to a web-layer class named `PersonController` (e.g. describing the Web Layer and instructing to invoke endpoints of `PersonController`), but both the template and the solution repositories provide a REST class named `PersonResource` (PersonResource.java). This naming mismatch can confuse students who search for a `PersonController` class to inspect or modify REST endpoints, and may cause uncertainty about where to implement or test controller-related functionality.
issues.suggested_fix: Make naming consistent. Either update the problem statement to refer to `PersonResource` instead of `PersonController`, or rename the REST class in the template and solution from `PersonResource` to `PersonController` (and update references/imports/tests accordingly). Updating the problem statement is the least invasive and preserves the provided code structure while removing potential confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement refers to the web layer controller as `PersonController` (problem description, line 22), but both the template and solution repositories implement the web controller class as `PersonResource` (class name in PersonResource.java). This mismatch can cause students to look for a `PersonController` class that does not exist in the starter code, increasing extraneous cognitive load and slowing down mapping from the textual system description to the actual code base.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the naming across artifacts. Either (A) update the problem statement to refer to the web layer class as `PersonResource` (so the textual description matches the provided code), or (B) rename the controller class files in template and solution from `PersonResource` to `PersonController`. Recommendation: update the problem statement to mention `PersonResource` (or note that the controller class in the code is named `PersonResource`) to minimize intrusive code changes while removing the student mapping confusion.
